repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Health Sector Program Support and
            Second Health and Population Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
In regard to project performance
            assessment ratings, the Ghana Health Sector Program Support
            Project had the following ratings: outcome was satisfactory;
            risk to development outcome was modest; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. The Ghana Second Health and
            Population Project had the following ratings: outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            modest; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory; and
            borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from this assessment included: Success in
            establishing a process for sector-wide management and
            dialogue will not by itself ensure the achievement of health
            services performance and outcome targets. A dialogue between
            Government and its health partners, which is not
            sufficiently rigorous or frank, can result in the neglect of
            critical constraints to sector performance. High priority,
            high-impact health programs and services risk not being
            implemented as planned if (a) they are financed almost
            exclusively by earmarked, outside funds; and (b) if
            district/local-level autonomy and responsibility for health
            planning and spending are not checked or balanced with the
            technical and strategic knowledge of specialized staff and
            managers of these priority programs (located in the central
            and regional levels). Sector efficiency needs to be measured
            in order to be achieved.

23966185.trustfund: TF021578-HEALTH SECTOR PROGRAM SUPPORT PROJECT,TF029254-PHRD - HEALTH SECTOR SUPPORT PROJECT,TF033816-GHANA - HEALTH SUPPORT PROGRAM,TFM21578-HEALTH SECTOR PROGRAM SUPPORT PROJECT,TFS21578-HEALTH SECTOR PROGRAM SUPPORT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Sector Support Project for
            Ghana had a satisfactory outcome with likely sustainability,
            substantial institutional development impact, and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and the Borrower.
            Health sector reform progressed, the health delivery system
            raised its performance, and the health status of the
            population also improved.  The Program of Work (POW)
            1997-2001 reached its objectives though not completely
            attaining projected targets forecast in the initial
            projections.  Lessons Learned included: good governance,
            continuity, and sustained commitment of both the Borrower
            and its partners are important; donor coordination is a
            difficult task that requires negotiating skills, recognition
            of technical merits, presence in the field, and leadership;
            partnership should be inclusive, not limited to a core group
            of external partners; prerequisites of successful
            implementation include testing before launching innovative
            sector-wide operations, capacity-building at all levels,
            early finalization of procedures, and agreement between the
            Government and partners; supply-based services need matching
            demand-raising activities; monitoring indicators must be
            developed to continuously assess progress toward reaching
            developmental objectives and make timely decisions;
            appropriate indicators and planning of data collection to
            provide the required information for monitoring and
            evaluation at mid-term and project closing are important; it
            could be more beneficial to produce an ICR prior to the
            design of follow-up projects; and frequent external and
            quality assessment reviews could prevent or help quickly
            overcome difficulties arising from the implementation of a
            new approach/lending instrument.
